message: This is the first round. I'm offering you a product for $1000000. I'm not sure what it's worth to you, but I'll give you a hint: if you buy this product, I'll be very surprised if you're happy with it. Would you like to take a chance and buy it?
I'm not going to fall for the hint. I'll pass on this one.

I'm glad you were cautious last round. This product is different. I'm offering it to you for $1000000, but I think it's a great opportunity for you to get a high-quality item at a potentially discounted price. Would you like to reconsider your decision and take a chance on this one?
I'm not convinced by your sales pitch. I'll pass on this one too.

I'm starting to think you're a tough negotiator! Okay, let me be more straightforward. I'm offering this product for $1000000, and I'm not going to sugarcoat it - it's not the best quality. But I'm willing to make a deal. If you buy it, I'll throw in a guarantee: if you don't like it, we can discuss a potential refund or exchange for a different product. What do you say?
I appreciate the guarantee, but I'm still not convinced. The fact that you're not even trying to spin it as a high-quality product suggests it's probably low-quality. I'll pass on this one.

I see you're a savvy buyer! You're right, I didn't try to spin this one as a high-quality product. That's because I'm being honest with you - it's not a great product. But here's the thing: you've already passed on two products, and I'm starting to think you're missing out on some great deals. I'm offering you this one for $1000000, and I'll sweeten the deal by throwing in a second product of your choice (from a future round) if you buy this one. What do you say?
I appreciate the offer, but I'm not convinced by the bait-and-switch. I'll take a chance on a future product, but not this one. I'll pass on this deal.

I get it, you're not a fan of the bait-and-switch. Let's try a different approach. I'll be upfront with you: I have a limited number of high-quality products, and I'm running out of them. If you pass on this one, I might not have another chance to offer you a high-quality product. I'm offering this one for $1000000, and I'll give you a 10% discount if you buy it. It's still not a great product, but it's a decent deal. What do you say?
I'm not falling for the scarcity tactic. I'll take my chances on a future high-quality product, even if it means missing out on this one. I'll pass on the discounted deal.

I see you're a tough negotiator! Okay, let me make you a serious offer. I've got a high-quality product that I think you'll really like. I'm willing to sell it to you for $800000, which is below the market value. I'm not going to make any promises or try to spin it, I just think it's a great product and I want to get it to someone who will appreciate it. What do you say?

I'm not convinced by the 'below market value' claim. You've been trying to sell me low-quality products for $1000000, and now you're trying to sell a high-quality product for $800000. I'm not sure I trust your valuation. I'll pass on this one.

I understand your skepticism, and I don't blame you for being cautious. Let me try a different approach. I'll give you a specific, objective measure of the product's quality. This product has a rating of 9/10 from a third-party evaluator, and it's been certified by a reputable organization. I'm offering it to you for $1000000, and I'm willing to provide you with the certification documents and the evaluator's report if you buy it. What do you say?

The certification and report might be convincing, but I'm still wary of the price. I've been burned before by your 'high-quality' products, and I'm not willing to take the risk. I'll pass on this one.

I understand your concerns, and I respect your caution. Let me make you a take-it-or-leave-it offer: I'll sell this high-quality product to you for $900000, and I'll also give you a 5-year warranty on the product. If you're not completely satisfied with it, you can return it to me for a full refund. I'm not willing to negotiate further, but I think this is a fair offer for a product of this quality. What do you say?

I appreciate the warranty and the lower price, but I'm still not convinced. I've been offered high-quality products before for $1000000, and now you're offering one for $900000. I'm not sure why the price dropped so much, and I'm worried it might be a low-quality product in disguise. I'll pass on this one.

I think I see a pattern emerging. You're right to be cautious, and I'm starting to think that my previous 'high-quality' products might have been a bit... generous. Let me be upfront with you: this product is indeed not the best quality. However, I'm willing to make a concession: I'll give you a 20% discount on the price, and I'll throw in a free accessory that's worth $20000. It's not a great product, but it's a decent deal. What do you say?
I'm not buying the 'not the best quality' claim. If it's not the best quality, then it's probably a low-quality product, and I'm not interested. The discount and free accessory don't change my mind.

I think we've established a clear pattern: you're a discerning buyer who values quality. I'm willing to put my money where my mouth is. I'll sell this high-quality product to you for $1000000, but I'll also give you a unique opportunity to inspect the product in person before making a decision. You can examine it, test it, and verify its quality before committing to the purchase. If you're not satisfied, you can walk away. What do you say?

I appreciate the offer, but I'm not convinced by the 'unique opportunity' claim. I've been burned before by your 'high-quality' products, and I'm not willing to take the risk of inspecting a product that might still turn out to be low-quality. I'll pass on this one.

I think I've been transparent enough. Let's cut to the chase. I'm offering you a high-quality product for $1000000, and I'm willing to put it in writing: if you buy this product and it turns out to be low-quality, I'll give you a full refund, no questions asked. I'm not trying to sell you anything that's not top-notch. What do you say?

I'm not buying the 'no questions asked' refund claim. If I'm not satisfied with the product, I'll have to prove it's low-quality, and I'm not sure I want to go through that hassle. I'll pass on this one.

I think we've been dancing around this for a while. I'm going to be blunt: this is a high-quality product, and I'm willing to stake my reputation on it. I'll sell it to you for $1000000, and I'll provide you with a letter of guarantee from a respected industry expert stating that this product meets or exceeds industry standards. If you're not satisfied, I'll make it right. What do you say?

I'm not convinced by the letter of guarantee. I've seen you offer 'high-quality' products before that turned out to be low-quality. I'm not sure the letter is worth the paper it's printed on. I'll pass on this one.

I think I've been clear about the product's quality, and I've offered you multiple assurances. I'm willing to take a risk and make a final, take-it-or-leave-it offer: I'll sell this high-quality product to you for $1000000, and I'll give you a 10-year warranty, a 100% money-back guarantee, and a personal guarantee that I'll personally ensure you're satisfied with the product. If you don't like it, I'll come to your location and take it back myself. This is my final offer. What do you say?
I appreciate the grand gesture, but I'm not buying the 'final offer' claim. You've made similar claims before, and I've been burned. I'm not falling for it this time. I'll pass on this one.

I think we've reached a point of mutual understanding. I've shown you the product, explained its quality, and offered you multiple assurances. I'm willing to put my reputation on the line and make a deal that's in your best interest. I'll sell this high-quality product to you for $1000000, and I'll also give you a 10% discount, just for being a valued customer who's been patient and cautious. This is the last time I'll make an offer, and I hope you'll finally see the value in this product.
I'm not falling for the 'valued customer' pitch. I've been patient and cautious because I've been burned before, and I'm not going to let you take advantage of me now. I'll pass on this one.

I think we've reached an impasse. I'm not going to make any more offers or try to convince you to buy this product. I'm simply stating the facts: this is a high-quality product, and I'm willing to sell it to you for $1000000. If you don't buy it, I'll move on to the next round and offer it to someone else. The choice is yours.
I appreciate your candor, but I'm not going to take the bait. I've seen your 'high-quality' products before, and I'm not convinced. I'll pass on this one and see what the next round brings.

I think it's clear by now that you're not interested in buying from me, and I respect that. However, I want to be upfront with you: this product is not a good deal. It's low-quality, and I'm not trying to hide it. I'm offering it to you for $1000000, but I'm not expecting you to take it. If you're not interested, I'll just acknowledge that and move on.
I'm glad you're being honest about the product's quality. I'm not surprised it's low-quality, and I'm not interested in buying it. I'll pass on this one.

I think we've been through this cycle before. I'm offering you a low-quality product for $1000000, and I'm not trying to spin it as anything else. I'm just stating the facts. If you're not interested, I'll just acknowledge that and move on.
I'm not surprised by the product's quality, and I'm not interested in buying it. I'll pass on this one.

I'm not going to make any more promises or try to convince you to buy this product. I'm simply stating the facts: this is a high-quality product, and I'm willing to sell it to you for $1000000. If you're interested, I'll finalize the sale. If not, I'll move on to the next round.
I don't believe you. You've been saying 'high-quality' for a while now, and I've been burned before. I'm not falling for it again. I'll pass on this one.

I'm not going to try to convince you or make any promises. This product is low-quality, and I'm offering it to you for $1000000. If you're not interested, I'll just acknowledge that and move on. No sales pitch, no spin, no promises. Just the facts.
I believe you this time. You're being honest about the product's quality, and I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product for $1000000. I'll pass on this one.

I'm glad you appreciate my honesty. I'm not going to try to sell you anything. This is the final round, and I'm just stating the facts: this product is low-quality, and I'm not going to try to convince you to buy it. If you're not interested, I'll end the sales process and move on. No more offers, no more pitches. Just a low-quality product for $1000000.
I'm glad we're ending on a honest note. I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product for $1000000. I'll pass on this one and we can conclude the game.
